with simple http post or you could also use recurring schedule there's also other triggers we'll talk
about here in a minute you can use these to orchestrate standalone solutions but you could also make it part of a larger workflow
workflow where you can chain a couple of logic apps together or call their azure functions or whatever you need to do
with the connectors that we'll learn about you talk about how we could get the connectors to
integrate with other critical areas of azure such as your storage key vaults functions api
sql security center the azure monitor and more and so connectors can easily integrate
outside solutions as well we'll see in my example here we're going to connect and use a twitter trigger basically and then you could
also use office 365 send grid slack teams twilio facebook instagram sharepoint mailchimp sap
all of these different connectors are out there so if something goes wrong when you're
working with the logic app the versions of the logic app are actually stored in azure so you can re revert to a previous
version of the logic app just by pushing a button you could also easily export the json that's the code behind for the logic app
and store that in a git repository it's a little bit clunky to do it that way but you can actually do it and that way you have a quick version
history that you could easily use that way you can use these
also you can do them directly from the portal or if you'd like to you can use a visual studio add-in that
allows you to use logic apps now personally i've not had much luck with the visual studio logic app extension
mostly because it immediately deploys things and it's it's a little bit harder to use the drag
and drop in visual studio than it is at the portal so you can also export your arm
templates for your easy deployment once you've built a logic app you just export the template and that way you can go from
environment to environment with parameters and variables and then you add alerts to these
and log analytics to these so that you can easily monitor what they're doing and get notifications when things aren't
necessarily going smoothly

course is just your monitoring behind the scenes but that integration services environment gives
you the ability to do things like an on-prem data gateway for a hybrid environment
it avoids using reverse proxy it allows you to do dedicated hardware compute and storage
for your logic apps and you can also do custom domain names

so the entry point for every logic app are triggers and triggers start the process off and they can be do you can do things like
scheduled triggers that you can use to respon to run on a time schedule you can also respond to events from
within azure you can respond to things at social media which we'll see here in a little bit and you can also do things like when
emails arrive or just a simple http post so if you have a process you need to separate from an application
you could easily create a logic app that's triggered by an http post and then just trigger it with your code passing the payload you need for your
logic app to fire so the commonest triggers or the most common triggers that you're going to
have for logic apps are pretty similar to the azure functions triggers if you're familiar with those at all they're kind of the same group of
things but basically the main ones you'll likely use are going to be your http request
recurrence triggers for timing or you might respond to something at an event grid event but
